results.title: Papua New Guinea: people in change: a social studies resource kit
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Dennis O'Rourke, Ian Dunlop and Peter Dimond
results.brief_description: This excellent kit attempts to answer the questions “What is traditional culture?” and “How and why do cultures change”. The kit comprises five films on two videocassettes, an audio tape and a comprehensive study guide for teachers which includes discussion topics and detailed background notes. The two video casssettes comprise films from “Towards Baruya manhood” - a series of ethnographic films which provide unique insights into the life of the Baruya tribe when their traditional culture was little changed by European contact. The second video contains “New Guinea Patrol”, which follows an Australian patrol officer in the Western Highlands during the period of colonial administration, and excerpts from “Yumi yet” which covers Papua New Guinea’s independence celebrations. All of these films are also available individually.

results.brief_description: Surveys social, political and economic development in Papua New Guinea, showing the main problems and the state of education, public health, communications and local and central government in preparation for independence.

results.title: Papua New Guinea
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Oceans of Dreams - Currents of Change Series”.
The largest of the newly independent South Pacific Nations (1975), Papua New Guinea, embodies many of the complexities facing the region. Papua New Guinea’s land mass includes vast mountain regions, fertile river valleys, coastal flat lands and tropical islands. More than 700 languages are spoken. Old enmities and conflicts still linger on. The greatest challenge facing PNG is to bind its people together in the spirit of one nation. The film looks at the distinctive Huli people, traditional and contemporary life and the challenges which face this exciting nation.

results.title: Papua and New Guinea, 1967
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Martin-Jones and Douglas White
results.brief_description: An overall survey of the Territories, emphasising economic, political and social development. Shows scenes of town and village life, local government and the House of Assembly, health and education and industries.

results.title: Papua and New Guinea development
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Martin-Jones and Douglas White
results.brief_description: Shows the immense potential and the industrial expansion of Papua New Guinea. Full economic development of the territory is an exercise in cooperation between the people themselves, the Administration and private investors.

results.title: Papua and New Guinea Command
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Frank Bagnall and Don Murray
results.brief_description: The Papua and New Guinea Command, recruited from indigenous peoples, is seen as a means of promoting unity in the Territory by bringing recruits from all regions together on an equal footing in a common force. Scenes of recruiting and military training are shown.

results.title: Papillon [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Franklin J. Schaffner, Allied Artists Pictures, Papillion Partnership and Robert Dorfmann
results.brief_description: Infamous as Papillon, so named after the intricate butterfly tattoo emblazoned upon his chest, petty criminal Henri Charriere (Steve McQueen) is framed for murder and transported to the penal colony of French Guiana to serve a life sentence. Imprisoned on Devil’s Island, Papillon is obsessed with the idea of freedom. He ceaselessly works on a means of escape with fellow prisoner, Dega (Dustin Hoffman), his spirit refusing to be broken by savage and humiliating treatment from his captors. This epic film lives up to the reputation of the best seller written by Henri Charriere on which it is based, aided by memorable performances by Hoffman and McQueen. Co-starring Victor Jory, Don Gordon and Anthony Zerbe.

results.title: Paperland: the bureaucrat observed
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Marrin Canell and Donald Brittain
results.brief_description: Bureaucracy shapes our lives and guides us from the cradle to the grave. This documentary lays bare the idiosyncrasies of bureaucracy whether in Canada, Austria, Hungary, the Vatican, or the Virgin Islands. Looks at the strengths and weaknesses common to all bureaucracies, the importance of paper and written authority, resistance to change, hierarchical organisation, absense of individual accountability. Examines the relationship between the public service and those it serves and the power politics at the top of the hierarchy. It also attempts to make the functioning of public service more comprehensible. The absurdities of bureaucratic behaviour are exposed with humour and irreverence. Written by Donald Brittain, Ronald Blummer and John T. Random. Narrated by Donald Brittain. (Awards: Toronto)
